title: Amid Rising Hot-Car Deaths, Auto Makers Agree to Back-Seat Alerts
text:
In an effort to prevent child heatstroke deaths, an alliance of major car makers announced an agreement to include rear-seat alert systems in nearly all new cars and trucks—a move that a key child-safety group called inadequate.

The agreement, which the auto industry had largely resisted in the past, pre-empts pending legislation in Congress that would mandate rear-seat monitoring features on U.S.-sold vehicles. The push, fueled with bipartisan support, comes after 53 children died in hot cars last year, marking a record, according to noheatstroke.org. So far this year, 38 children have died from vehicular heatstroke.

The Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers and the Association of Global Automakers—trade groups that represent the bulk of domestic- and international-made cars and trucks in the U.S. market—on Wednesday said they will add rear-seat reminder systems on new cars by model year 2025 or sooner. These alerts will at a minimum include auditory and visual cues to drivers that remind them to check the back seat before leaving the car, the groups say.

Child-safety advocates have pushed for years for a technological solution to stop hot-car deaths. However, many consider motion-detection technology crucial to such back-seat alert systems—a technology that Wednesday’s agreement doesn’t stipulate.

Among systems covered by the auto makers’ agreement are door-sequencing technology. When a rear door is opened at the beginning of a trip, it tracks if it is opened again at its conclusion, sounding an alert if not.

Safety advocates say that solution isn’t adequate because the system can reset itself when the car is turned off, for instance if a driver stops for gas. It also wouldn’t help in the approximately 25% of heatstroke cases where children get into cars on their own and get trapped, they say.

“The proposed agreement is inadequate and will give families a false sense of security,” child-safety group Kidsandcars.org said. “A simple ‘alert’ to check the back seat when the engine is turned off is not enough.” The group also said a voluntary agreement, as opposed to a law, isn’t adequate to protect consumers.

The number of hot-car deaths has been increasing despite efforts from child-safety groups, hospital-education programs, product developers and a steady stream of media coverage. These efforts face the same challenge: Many people don’t believe this could ever happen to them. “As most of these deaths are caused by children being unintentionally left in vehicles, our members are taking action to prevent these tragic losses,” Association of Global Automakers chief executive John Bozzella said in a statement.

“I’m not saying this is a perfect solution and technology will always improve, but this gets us a long way toward where we need to be, and gets us there quicker than hoping the bill gets floor time in the House and Senate, gets to conference, and gets to the president,” said Sen. Roger Wicker (R., Miss.), chairman of the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation, who sponsored the Senate bill along with Sens. Maria Cantwell (D.,Wash.) and Richard Blumenthal (D., Conn.). “This is a huge win and babies are going to live because of this.”

Rep. Tim Ryan (D., Ohio), who sponsored the House legislation, criticized the commitment’s voluntary nature and said the target date of 2025 was too slow. “It should be mandated,” he said in a statement. “The lives of our children are too important to slow roll the use of available technology.”

Janette Fennell, president and founder of kidsandcars.org, said the group will continue to pursue legislation requiring cars to install technology that can detect a back-seat occupant. “We are going to be pushing big-time to get a federal regulation in place,” Ms. Fennell said. Hyundai and Kia already offer motion-detection capabilities.

Doors already have sensors in them, so the additional costs to auto makers of a door-based reminder would be minimal, said Sam Abuelsamid, an automotive-technology analyst at Navigant Research. “It’s just a matter of adding software that would cost a few dollars per car at most, probably less,” Mr. Abuelsamid said.

Ultrasonic motion sensors are relatively inexpensive and likely cost less than $10 for each sensor, he said. But added to the software costs, the extra hardware adds a layer of complexity that would make for higher production costs than the door-based system, he said.

Several auto makers already offer rear-seat reminder systems or have committed to installing different technologies to alert drivers to check the back seat. General Motors began offering reminder systems in 2016. Nissan last year made a similar pledge, and Hyundai and Honda this summer committed to using reminder technology on most of their cars by 2022. Ford said Wednesday that it will begin to roll out its rear-occupant alert system in some of its 2020 model year vehicles and will fully roll it out well ahead of the 2025 model-year deadline.

Write to Ellen Byron at ellen.byron@wsj.com
description: Industry groups plan rear-seat technology on nearly all cars and trucks by 2025 to help avoid children being left in cars; child-safety group calls the plan inadequate.
